Comment: Indeed, which is why wealthy people don’t tend to have all *that* many more kids, barring obvious outliers like Elon Musk. Often, both parents are still working at far higher rates than they were 50 years ago, and due to a variety of factors like Baumol’s cost disease, changing social and class structures, and the Western abandonment of multigenerational family housing, they still don’t have the kind of time or support necessary to have large families.   That, combined with an aging population, supports an obvious but unpalatable solution—grandparents, aunts, and uncles engaging in collective child-rearing, as had been the case for countless eons before the rise of urbanization, single-family homes, and suburbia. Historically speaking, due to things like disease and overcrowding, big cities were *universally* a population sink that was propped up by an influx of opportunity-seekers from the vastly more populous small towns and surrounding rural areas.  Today, though, 58% of the world population lives in cities, and that’s expected to rise to 68% in 2035. Cities *were* briefly able to grow populations in the early to mid 20th century due to better health standards, but rent-seeking, declining community trust and participation, lacking civic-mindedness, and artificial housing scarcity have all eroded that away. Cities no longer feel child-friendly or family-oriented. They are atomized, individualized. And that brings with it low fertility rates as sure as can be.
